TV Review: Doctor Who Series 8 Episode 12: 'Death in Heaven'

09/11/2014

The Doctor and Missy face off in the Doctor Who series finale. Alex Killeen reviews.

Image by

By James Bithell

Rating: This review contains spoilers This week's Doctor Who was set up to be explosive as the mysterious Missy subplot finally culminated in the reveal of her identity as The Master- a surprise that was not exactly a surprise for many viewers. And in many ways, it delivered; unfortunately, in others it may not have. The Cybermen finally being back in their latest iteration was a welcome addition to the season finale, as their destructive power and new methods of upgrading were terrifying and disturbing - still not sure if it's suitable for Doctor Who though. And welcome returners came in the form of UNIT who, although absent since the 50th anniversary, made a fitting comeback to rescue The Doctor and begin some sort of retaliation. Unfortunately, and obviously, Missy is fifty steps ahead because she just wouldn't be The Master if she weren't. Michelle Gomez has to be commended in her portrayal of Missy because while it's easy to see the return of Moffat's classic female bad guy, when it comes to Missy, all the credit can't be given to the writer. The actress fills that role with the zaniness and 'bananas' that we've come to expect from The Master ever since John Simm. And ultimately, this episode was full of such great performances. For the first time Danny Pink seemed a viable part of the plot instead of a tacked-on romantic interest. His need for emotional inhibition was moving to no end and Clara's reactions to this only exemplified the connection the two shared. Indeed when the episode started and Clara claimed "I am The Doctor" eyes everywhere probably rolled but thankfully Jenna-Louise Coleman levelled her out as she reacted to her discovery of Danny and attempted to save him. However, amongst the excellent back-to-forth between Missy and The Doctor, the latter actually seemed to be at a massive disadvantage. Missy's murder of Osgood and the destruction of UNIT's plane lead to an excellently funny sequence in which The Doctor skydives into the TARDIS, and while it was actually quite 'action-heroesque', many Who fans were probably just laughing. And for once, the special effects didn't actually look too bad. After this though, when emotion and intelligence begins, it may have started to fall apart. Missy's plan of handing over the army to The Doctor was inspired. It's always been a point since Who's return in 2005 that The Doctor does, accidentally and inherently, inspire those around him to fight for him, so the whole plan actually made sense. Also, Missy's desperation to prove some sort of similarity between the two characters seems viable- The Master has always had a problem with The Doctor's pride in his humanity. This is where it gets rocky. When Capaldi's Doctor realised he was just an idiot with a TARDIS, his handing over to Danny was quite a warm tale of reconciliation between the two characters. But it can't help but feel a bit of an easy way out. From this episode alone we saw that Missy had everything planned, so why not this? Her subsequent apparent death might cause arouse some irk with some viewers. It all just felt too easy. Yet, it might not all look how it seems, who knows? Also, the cameo at the end of this scene was awesome, no matter what anyone says. The ending was subsequently heart breaking as well. To see the couple who have spent their time bickering and yet caring for each depart on such terms was quite upsetting. Obviously they are both shielded and defensive so it's an excellent way to temporarily close their relationship. All in all, we had a strong ending here. It was action-packed, full of Cybermen (creepy as ever), and the performances were spot on but unfortunately, when it comes to Missy and the fall of her plan, everything just felt a bit too simple. Maybe something more will be revealed, but we won't know until another whole season. Where is Gallifrey? Did Missy really die? What will happen between The Doctor and Clara? We'll get some answers at Christmas. And apparently we'll get Santa too...let's be quiet about that one.
